answer_html: \(\displaystyle 2009^{2012} \equiv 9^{1202} \equiv (9^{400})^{3}9^{2} \equiv 81 \mod{1000}\)and so the last three digits are 081.
answer_latex: $\displaystyle 2009^{2012} \equiv 9^{1202} \equiv (9^{400})^{3}9^{2} \equiv 81 \mod{1000}$and so the last three digits are 081.
hints_raw:
Consider the number modulo 1000.
Use Euler's theorem.
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
Euler’s theorem tells us that if \(\displaystyle \gcd(a,1000)=1\) then

\(\displaystyle a^{\phi(1000)} \equiv a^{\phi(8)\phi(125)} \equiv a^{4\cdot 100} \equiv a^{400} \equiv 1 \mod{1000}\).

Thus, we have

\(\displaystyle 2009^{2012} \equiv 9^{1202} \equiv (9^{400})^{3}9^{2} \equiv 81 \mod{1000}\)

and so the last three digits are 081.
sols_latex:
Euler's theorem tells us that if $\displaystyle \gcd(a,1000)=1$ then

$\displaystyle a^{\phi(1000)} \equiv a^{\phi(8)\phi(125)} \equiv a^{4\cdot 100} \equiv a^{400} \equiv 1 \mod{1000}$.

Thus, we have

$\displaystyle 2009^{2012} \equiv 9^{1202} \equiv (9^{400})^{3}9^{2} \equiv 81 \mod{1000}$

and so the last three digits are 081.
sols_raw:
Euler's theorem tells us that if <math> \displaystyle \gcd(a,1000)=1</math> then

<math> \displaystyle a^{\phi(1000)} \equiv a^{\phi(8)\phi(125)} \equiv a^{4\cdot 100} \equiv a^{400} \equiv 1 \mod{1000}</math>.

Thus, we have 

<math> \displaystyle 2009^{2012} \equiv 9^{1202} \equiv (9^{400})^{3}9^{2} \equiv 81 \mod{1000}</math>

and so the last three digits are 081.
statement_html: Find the last three digits of the decimal expansion of \(\displaystyle 2009^{1202}\).
statement_latex:
Find the last three digits of the decimal expansion of
$\displaystyle 2009^{1202}$.
statement_raw: Find the last three digits of the decimal expansion of <math> \displaystyle 2009^{1202}</math>.
